Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 06:48PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: I'm so sorry you are dealing with this, and while I don't have the same experience as you I do know that somewhere on here I saw some related threads -- try scanning back a few pages.  I remember thinking that there was good info there. Be glad your PS is on top of this -- my situation went pretty bad and now I have an open wound to deal with...I wish I had my doc do what yours is doing. Good luck and hang in there!
Posts.Title: draining of seroma rkt rkt

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 04:47PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: Yes, yes, yes, protein is VERY important.  I am actually a vegan (strict vegetarian) and was so for years before my cancer.  Protein is usually abundant in a plant based diet, meat-eaters typically get way more than needed.  But when it comes to a trauma like this type of surgery, or even chemo (for those that need it) extra protein is crucial.  Good plant sources are:  whole grains, beans, nuts, seitan (wheat gluten), whole grain products like certain pastas & breads, moderate amounts of soy. I say "moderate amounts of soy" because there's alot of controversy about soy and those of us with hormone positive cancers.  This is what my research has told me:  soy protein isolate, the stuff that they cram into protein bars, powders and even some fake meat products, is not natural and too conentrated...this is not healthy.  But minimally processed soy, such as tofu, tempeh, edamame and unsweetened soy milk are a more natural form of the bean and the proteins are not overly concentrated enough to mess with hormone levels.  In fact, in countries where this type of soy is consumed regularly there are MUCH lower rates of BC (like practically none!)  Still, there's much research to be done on the issue so my personal approach is to limit my soy intake to a couple times per week and only the minimally processed stuff. Not sure you needed all this info,lol, but hope it helps anyway!
Posts.Title: draining of seroma rkt rkt

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 06:41PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: Thank you Binny, I was so hoping you would answer my plea for help!  Would they do arm wrapping if there is no swelling or difference in the skin?  Even without the Ldex thing my arm shows no swelling and the skin is totally normal.  My breast, side & back are the only places that could be said to have swelling on me so far, tho I do have the symptoms of various sensations in the arm. Oh, and no one has used any heat on my shoulder, I've read here not to ever do that so I wouldn't have let them.  The LE PT just did gentle massage and then followed w/MLD.  She said that was okay since if any lymph was drawn to that area she would be redirecting the flow with the MLD after -- does that sound right? I just had no idea LE could be so painful...I was fearful of the disfigurement but this pain is getting to me. Again, thank you SOOOOO much Binny (and anyone else that responds)
Posts.Title: How long should it take for treatment to show results? Kayleigh3483 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 04:00PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: Thank you again BInny -- and that makes sense, treating the whole quadrant as a potential area.  I also totally got what you meant by not wanting to see it when it came to your arm LE.  Many of my symptoms fit LE, which is why I went ASAP to the LE PT, but since some of my symptoms detour from the typical, I keep secretly hoping maybe it's not.  Little by little I'm arriving at acceptance that I probably do have LE that is being exacerbated (or triggered, take your pick) by some other potential probs. Speaking of which, KS1, I wondered about the neuropathy too, since it was after beginning Taxotere that my symptoms began.  But my onc says that the peripheral neuropathy from taxanes starts in the fingers (or toes) and works its way up the arms (or legs)...and that it is bilateral, never just on one side.  But it does have me wondering...I have often not fit the typical model in this breast cancer journey, so who knows?
Posts.Title: How long should it take for treatment to show results? Kayleigh3483 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 06:08PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: This thread has made me laugh and cry and scream and giggle -- so glad I read it!  I'm in the lucky club of having a wonderful DH, the kind of man that empties drains and bandages necrotic wounds.  I had a uni mx so I still have a "working" boob...but it's on vacation for the moment. The thought of sex, emotionally, is too much for me.  Physically I could totally do it, but there would be that moment when he would normally reach for my breasts....and I'd be so damned sad it just wouldn't work. He'd do whatever I want...touch, no touch, anything I wanted.  But it's in MY head that it would be the problem.  DH's seen me naked since the surgery, in fact he looked before I did, lol.  He still wants me, says I am beautiful, that he misses me...no pressure, he just wants me to know that he still sees me that way.  Truthfully, I think I look even better than before the surgery in some ways, the tummy tuck portion of this did my body a huge solid ;)  But still...there'd be that moment...and what would I want?  Touch it?  Don't?  Touch the "real" one only? I can't picture it. Thank you all for sharing so much...it's made me feel less alone.

Posts.Title: recon breast biopsy, lung biopsy & LE Kayleigh3483 Suzybelle

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 05:58PM - edited Aug 30, 2009 06:01PM by Kayleigh3483 Same thing happened to me -- clear during surgery (uni skin/nip sparing mx w/immed ped TRAM recon) then the final path report showed .7mm in 1st of 2 sentinel nodes. My surgeon felt chemo will take care of it and doesn't recomend doing axillary dissection.  One onc wanted me to remove more nodes but changed his mind after speaking to the surgeon.  A second oncologist wants me to have axillary removed no matter what. There are two additional issues for me -- one is that I had skin necrosis and have an open wound so no surgery for me until after chemo in order to give the wound time to heal.  However that defeats one of the purposes, namely that when they remove the rest of the axillary thanks to chemo they will most likely all show as clear...whether they were before chemo or not.  So I won't really know if there was more lymph nodes involved. The other issue is that my surgeon thinks my positive sentinel node was likely from displacement -- sometimes during biopsies or surgeries microscopic cancer cells can be displaced from the original tumor and end up in the first node.  So how do I know if the cancer migrated there of its own volition or if it got there via surgery?  I don't. Since I'm going to do chemo and since there is a question about whether or not to do an axillary dissection in my case...and since I had an Oncotype score of 16, I'm probably going to forgoe the removal of any more nodes.  Either way, I have time to think. My advice?  No matter what, if there is only a microinvasion insist that you get Oncotype done anyway...even if it doesn't help decide about chemo there is valuable info to be had about one's specific tumor that you might need down the line - who knows?  Lots of docs won't do Oncotype w/any positive nodes but I insisted and am glad to have that info now. In any case, much good luck to all!
Posts.Title: Separate surgery--nodes removed Sunshine1958 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 08:38AM Kayleigh3483 wrote: Hi Sunshine! Well, it sounded extreme to me too at first but so far between 3 docs (1 surg, 2 onc) they all concur that chemo is needed...I had 3 tumors, the largest of which was 1.3 cm.  But otherwise I've got good stats, as it were, strongly ER/PR + and HER2 - etc. I'm still seeking opinions and have some time while I'm waiting for my necrotic wound issue to heal. Oncotype is a 21 gene assay that has been used for those with node negative BC as a tool to determine the efficacy of chemo for preventing a recurrence.  The scores are divided into low, intermediate and high and assigned a number.  I'm in the low group (18&under) which would probably mean that without my little smidge of micromets in that pesky node I would be able to skip chemo and go straight to hormones.  That's why I'm seeking a number of opinions so I don't end up going overboard. It's a tough decision...chemo can wreak havoc certainly, but so can removing more nodes, as Artemis said, the more they yank, the higher the risk of lymphedema.  I've said it before, these are decisions not fit for a mortal. May we all be healed by whatever choices we make!
Posts.Title: Separate surgery--nodes removed Sunshine1958 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 11:39AM - edited Sep 4, 2009 11:42AM by Kayleigh3483 I'll give you the flip side of this choice -- altho my dx is different from yours.  I chose to leave my other breast because I wasn't willing to lose a healthy body part.  I was also determined to have a reconstruction done that matched my remaining breast so as not to need mastopexy -- right down to finding a PS who would make me a new, saggy 45yo breast, lol. For some women the focus is about getting peace of mind, which of course is totally rational and understandable.  But for me personally, with my own unique psychological make-up, it was about coming out of this as unscathed as possible and emotionally that meant doing the minimal amount of surgery/treatment I needed.  I want to be safe, but I couldn't deal with doing anything more than necessary. Again, that's what has worked for me so far.  I think you need to assess the whole picture, the kind of person you are.  Try to project yourself 10 years from now...what do you think is important?  Even try to imagine what you'd feel like if the cancer came back.  For me, I felt I would be able to face it again if I had to.  If that thought sends terror thru your veins than your needs are clearly different than mine. Each of us has to fight this in the best way we can.  That being said, these are some of the MOST difficult decision we could ever be faced with.  They don't seem fit for mortals to make.  We just have to do the best we can.  May the choices you make fill you with peace & health. PS:  I don't want to give you medical advice, but is there a reason that you need to rush to make this decision before MRI's and BRCA testing?  I would think you have time to do these things beforehand.  The more info you make your decision armed with, the better.  But of course, I may not be understanding your situation clearly.

From what I've read, an incision should never drain...learn from my unfortunate situation, if your incision is draining MAKE YOUR DOCTOR take care of it.  It might turn out fine, but it might not.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 04:29PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: I am going thru something sort of similar I think -- about a day or so after my drains were pulled I began seeping from my incision (a single line a few inches long from the edge of my areola back towards my armpit) -- I have to keep a gauze bandage on it and change it maybe three times a day.  We also gently swab the area with sterile saline before putting on the new bandage.  My fluid is also orangey colored. When we called the PS there was no doc for us to talk to (late on a Fri) but the nurse said it happens and is really no big deal.  But we're planning to phone on Mon anyway.  Oh, and the visitng nurse didn't seem too concerned either, as long as none of the skin was red and I had no pain or fever. I'm sorry you are having such a tough time with all this...it sounds like you've been thru the ringer.  I hope whatever happens that your situation is resolved ASAP.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 03:26PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: I'm experiencing mysterious arm symptoms myself -- might be LE, might not.  I too went to a PT.  It's scary and frustrating at the same time. May I make two suggestions?  First, make sure your PT was LANA certified -- they are the ones that really know their stuff when it comes to LE.  Second, you should post this on the Lymphedema board -- several women over there are AMAZINGLY helpful and you might get some needed advice.  For instance, I thought I heard that cording can put you at risk for developing LE...so you may need to be monitored more closely or do exercises, etc. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Arm Pain 18 Mths After Surgery Lainey64 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 07:40PM Kayleigh3483 wrote: I was in a similar situation, totally healthy left breast but IDC in right.  Am today 12 days out from unilateral skin/nipple sparing mast w/immed ped TRAM recon. I saw 7 plastic surgeons and several breast cancer surgeons in my search for the right team.  Most didn't offer me nipple sparing and many tried to push bilateral on me -- frankly it seemed more an issue of symmetry than health! Also, most PS's wouldn't hear of trying to match my new breast to my old 45yo saggy one...but that's what I wanted.  I wanted to do no mastopexy on Lefty if I could help it. Yet now after surgery, after going through what I have so far, I can actually better understand the reasons for wanting bilat -- the thought of ever having to do this again is extremely daunting.  But in the end I was personally willing to take that chance. I will be vigilant and monitored closely...I can handle that but for some it would be a constant fear, a deep seeded worry that might interfere with qualilty of life. Not to mention that alot depends on the individual's health history/status -- that comes down to science & odds. I have learned that every woman is different when it comes to breast cancer and how she chooses to fight...and I think knowing yourself is probably the best weapon one has :)

Posts.Title: SNB not clear after all, so confused? Kayleigh3483 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 11:04AM Kayleigh3483 wrote: I have not experienced your situation but did deal with infertility and had a baby just 2 yrs before my diagnosis -- in fact, I was breastfeeding my DS when I found the lumps.  I also had my children at 38 & 43, and had a few miscarriages so your post attracted my attention.  I'm sorry for your loss. I'm not sure how pregnancy would effect you, altho being ER+ no doubt it could.  But there are different types of estrogen and the high levels of pregnancy might not be the estrogen that feeds breast cancer.  I really don't know enough about it to comment, but... ...what you need are two things:  a consult with a board certified reproductive endocrinologist and if it's a go then you need a perinatologist to oversee your pregnancy rather than an OB as you would be considered high risk. Either way, I understand your thinking about this.  I have another health issue (blood clotting) that made me high risk, discovered w/my last pregnancy.  I have a boy(3) & girl(8), both healthy...and now breast cancer.  Yet the thought that I will go into menopause and have that choice taken from me is disturbing, even tho I probably wouldn't have had anymore children anyway at 46.  I even momentarily considered freezing some eggs or creating embryos for IVF...just so I don't lose anymore to this damned cancer...crazy as that sounds. I wish you the very best and hope you get the answers you want!
